awd_titl_txt: CPS: Small: Real-Time Machine Learning-based Control of Human Cyber-Physical Balance Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is the advancement of machine learning dynamic models and real-time control systems for human cyber-physical balance systems. Ranging from biped walkers and human bicycle riding to human-controlled helicopters, human cyber-physical balance systems maintain challenging tasks of simultaneously trajectory-tracking and unstable platforms balancing. Although many physical models were developed in past decades, it is still challenging to safely and effectively operate these human-in-the-loop balance machines in highly variable, uncertain environments. This project will develop machine learning-based mathematical models and robust control strategies for human cyber-physical balance systems. The researchers will also develop a number of integrated research and education programs to attract students from underrepresented groups into engineering and involve undergraduate students into research.

Human cyber-physical balance systems involve human movements as physical and forceful interactions with unstable, underactuated platforms. It is challenging to capture and control physical human-machine or human-robot interactions in complex, uncertain environments. This project will focus on: (1) development of machine learning-based models and characterization for human cyber-physical balance systems; (2) development of new hardware/software co-design accelerated learning-based real-time control to handle human cyber-physical balance system dynamics in highly variable, uncertain environments; and (3) robotic testbeds development, experimental validation and performance evaluation. The integration of data-driven model and learning-based control strategies, along with the hardware/software co-design enabled real-time implementation, provides new perspectives on performance enhancement of safety-critical or mission-critical cyber-physical systems in dynamic, uncertain environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

por.por_cntn:
This project will contribute to the national welfare, health and prosperity by advancing machine learning dynamic models and real-time control systems for human cyber-physical balance systems. Ranging from biped walkers and human bicycle riding to human-controlled helicopters, human cyber-physical balance systems represent a broad class of human-in-the-loop underactuated robots or machines that maintain challenging tasks of trajectory-tracking and unstable platforms balancing. Although model-based control methods are developed in past decades, it is still challenging to safely and effectively operate these human-in-the-loop balance machines in highly variable, uncertain environments. The objective of this project is to develop machine learning-based mathematical models and robust real-time control strategies for human cyber-physical balance systems.

Over the past five years, the PIs have accomplished various research tasks to develop new machine learning-based modeling and real-time control strategies for human cyber-physical balance systems. The main outcomes of the project lie in several aspects: (1) a set of Gaussian process (GP)-based control frameworks for underactuated balance systems with guaranteed performance; (2) a new hardware architecture and accelerator that provided significant performance improvement than the general-purpose CPU to implement GP and advanced stochastic decomposition; (3) an innovative machine learning-based human intention detection that leveraged the fusion of electroencephalography (EEG) and inertial measurement unit (IMU) data with applications to exoskeleton-assisted human sit-to-stand (STS) locomotion; (4) several new experimental platforms such as the bikebot-manipulator system and wearable knee exoskeletons; (5) a new US-India collaboration between the PIs at Rutgers University and an Indian partner at Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Kanpur campus; and (6) a new startup company that was partially built on the research outcomes of this project. More than 10 journal publications and 9 conference presentations have been produced and supported by the project. A number of research activities were integrated into the education programs to attract students from underrepresented groups into engineering fields, such as participating the Rutgers SUPER and LSAMP programs and hosting more than 3 freshmen female students, supporting more than 3 senior design projects, and attracting more than 10 undergraduate students to conduct research assistance.

 


Last Modified: 03/22/2025
Modified by: Jingang Yi
